The Real Leadership Lessons of Steve Jobs

Six months after job's death, the author of his best-selling biography identifies the practice that every CEO can try to. by Walter Isaacson

His saga is the entrepreneurial creation myth writ large: Steve Jobs cofounded Apple in his parent's garage in 1976, was ousted in 1985, returned to rescue it from near bankruptcy in 1997, and by the time he died, in October 2011, had built it into the world's most valuable company. Along the way he helped to transform seven industries: personal computing, animated movies, music phones, tablet computing, retail stores, and digital publishing. He thus belongs in the pantheo of America's great innovators, along with the Thomas Edison, Henry Fored, and Walt Disney. None of these men was a saint, but long their personalities are forgotten, history will remember how they applied imagination to technology and business.

"The people who are crazy enough to think they can change the world are the ones who do."
- Apple's "Think Different"commercial, 1997
